article.title: Driving better science diplomacy in the face of global challenges
article.teaser: From pandemics to climate change, we need to meet the cross-border challenges facing us today. This makes tightening the ties between science and diplomacy more imperative than ever, so the S4D4C project is seeking to bring the two closer.

section.sectionBody:
Food safety and security, how we manage pandemics, the challenges of cyber security and the potential of artificial intelligence: just a few examples of where science and foreign policy are closely intertwined. The https://www.s4d4c.eu/ (S4D4C project) aimed to suggest ways of creating a space in which people can interact, focusing on shared interests that require collective action.
â€œThe opportunities science and science cooperation offer European Union foreign policy are underexploited,â€ explains project coordinator Elke Dall, who is based at the https://www.zsi.at/en/home (Centre for Social Innovation), in Austria.
While S4D4C feels the EUâ€™s foreign policy landscape is increasingly better set up to develop and exploit science diplomacy, the scientific and diplomatic communities often do not communicate with each other. It is this that the project sought to address.
â€œWe developed a https://www.s4d4c.eu/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/S4D4C-Calling-for-a-Systemic-Change-Policy-Report-v2.0-1.pdf (vision for EU science diplomacy) that puts the need to address global challenges at its heart.â€
These challenges are many. S4D4C had climate change adaptation and mitigation in mind and delved into water diplomacy as a case study. The cooperation instruments used by Europe and Africa to address food security were also considered.
Overall, https://www.s4d4c.eu/s4d4c-cases/ (nine case studies) were developed by international and interdisciplinary teams from the https://www.s4d4c.eu/project-partners/ (ten project partner organisations), looking for examples of different national approaches, or specific instruments, that drive science diplomacy for addressing global challenges.
â€œWe were interested to note that science diplomacy is not something happening at embassies: itâ€™s a concept that can be relevant for every researcher and host organisation. Itâ€™s not yet a career path, but we wanted to raise awareness about the need to professionalise this interaction.â€

As with many other projects, S4D4C was affected by the COVID-19 crisis. â€œWe had to cancel meetings and change our work plan. Yet, the crisis also inspired us to https://www.s4d4c.eu/what-everyone-is-talking-about-covid-19-and-science-diplomacy/ (put forward a few thoughts about the science diplomacy aspects of the pandemic) and some https://www.s4d4c.eu/policy-brief-building-better-science-diplomacy-for-global-challenges-insights-from-the-covid-19-crisis/ (policy recommendations).â€
These included, for example, the creation of interactive spaces, the promotion of bidirectional science and diplomacy fluency, to engage the full spectrum of science, including social sciences.
â€œWe aim to ensure open and interpretable science, and for the EU to exert bold, values-based leadership,â€ says Dall.
The pandemic galvanised the debate and the project managed to continue their work despite the associated constraints. The team organised three major networking meetings â€“ one in https://www.s4d4c.eu/s4d4c-1st-global-meeting/ (Madrid) in 2018, one in https://www.s4d4c.eu/berlin-networking-meeting/ (Berlin) in 2019 and the last one https://www.s4d4c.eu/announcement-of-the-s4d4cs-final-networking-meeting/ (online) in 2021 â€“ and a https://www.s4d4c.eu/european-science-diplomacy-online-course/ (massive open online course).
â€œWe were delighted to see the enthusiasm shown at the events and, in particular, for the online course which has been completed by more than 1 000 people so far,â€ Dall notes.

section.sectionTitle: The multiple benefits of science diplomacy
section.sectionBody:
S4D4C believes that science and foreign policy are intertwined in many ways, not just as a means of understanding contexts more clearly.
â€œScience diplomacy also supports the internationalisation of science, for example by facilitating the agreements that enable bilateral and multilateral cooperation or transnational research infrastructures,â€ says Dall.
She feels scientific cooperation can also be a means to facilitate contacts between countries that are normally not involved with each other.
â€œWe believe that through the https://www.s4d4c.eu/s4d4c-1st-global-meeting/the-madrid-declaration-on-science-diplomacy/ (Madrid Declaration on Science Diplomacy), 2019, and the foundation of the https://www.science-diplomacy.eu/ (European Union Science Diplomacy Alliance) in 2021, we have been able to provide key milestones towards these goals.
The Alliance, a direct outcome of the collaboration between S4D4C and related projects, is open for other stakeholders to join and aims to enhance understanding and competences in the field in the coming years,â€ Dall adds.

article.keywords: S4D4C, science, diplomacy, foreign policy, Centre for Social Innovation, internationalisation of science, scientific cooperation

result.title: Guidebook for upgraded decision-making matrix
result.description: UPRC and adelphi will work together to further develop and enhance the PROSPECT Recommendations-Decision Matrix tool. This self-assessment tool was deployed in PROSPECT and contains a set of questions, which help to determine which financing scheme will be the most suitable for the local authority to implement for local sustainable energy and climate project investments. It consists an easy-to-grasp checklist that assists a local authority in its first decision-making steps to decide against a set of financing alternatives. The tool will be expanded to provide also other sectors of recommendation (e.g., Transport) or innovative schemes and will be well-adjusted utilizing Adelphiâ€™s financial expertise. The Matrix will contain a quick readiness check before proceeding to the financial scheme selection. Aim is to create a comprehensive quick and easy to use tool for PAs that do not have time to participate in the PROSPECT+ project or to go through the learning materials.

article.title: Heat recovery innovation powers continuous industrial furnaces
article.teaser: The EcoStock project adapted a first-of-its-kind heat recovery solution, based on recycled refractory ceramics, to continuous industrial furnaces for better energy efficiency, reduced CO2 emissions and lower costs.

section.sectionBody:
According to Guilhem Dejean from energy specialists https://ecotechceram.com/en/ (Eco-Tech Ceram), over a third of the energy consumed by fossil fuel-powered heavy industry is lost as heat â€“ equivalent to 2 450 megatonnes of CO2 per year, globally.
As many energy efficiency solutions designed to avoid this by recovering lost heat are expensive and time-consuming to install, manufacturers are often reluctant to adopt them.
The most common, the heat exchanger, is effective but is limited to temperatures below 600 Â°C, and with no https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phase-change_material (phase shift), recovered heat has to be used immediately.
But the barrier to adoption remains more economic, than technical.
â€œManufacturers need short-term profitability and so are tempted by quick-fix energy efficiency solutions,â€ explains Dejean, project coordinator of the EU-funded EcoStock project.
Eco-Tech Ceram, the projectâ€™s host, had previously designed a solution for intermittent industrial furnaces that not only recovers heat, but uses electric power to increase its temperature.
The EcoStock project has enabled the team to now validate the performance of its solution in a continuous industrial furnace, installed at Villeroy & Bochâ€™s luxury ceramics factory in Valence dâ€™Agen, France.
â€œWe extracted more waste heat from the furnace than we had calculated, giving us greater combustion efficiency than initially expected,â€ adds Dejean. â€œRaising the temperature of recovered heat like this is a first for industrial furnaces.â€

The projectâ€™s solution is based on two innovations: the use of industrial waste ceramics to store the heat and their installation into a thermal energy storage unit, called EcoStock.
The system was co-constructed with luxury ceramics manufacturer Villeroy and Boch. The set-up included the EcoStock device, a power to heat facility, fans, a 150 metre furnace tunnel and a chimney.
Waste heat is recovered from the tunnel kiln at 450 Â°C, then raised to 600 Â°C using the power to heat facility (which converts electricity into heat using electrical resistance). This heat is then stored in the EcoStock device.
â€œInstead of only using industrial waste heat, we can simultaneously use off-peak low-cost grid electricity or even that from renewables. While, at more expensive peak times, we can use the heat previously accumulated in the EcoStock,â€ notes Dejean.
â€œIn our tests, despite working with a plantâ€™s core element â€“ a 150 metre long furnace with over 50 burners â€“ we recovered waste heat without disrupting the industrial process.â€

The EcoStock innovation could significantly contribute to European ambitions to decarbonise industry, while also showcasing European enterpriseâ€™s ability to lead the green industrial revolution.
â€œWeâ€™ve demonstrated that an innovative industrial solution can reduce the natural gas consumption of an industrial site in a sustainable and profitable way,â€ says Dejean.
To help businesses make the initial investment required, Eco-Tech Ceram also offers a third-party financing solution, ETC Invest, making the investment more appealing to manufacturers.
The team is now working to increase the size of their device so that it can supply all the burners of a continuous furnace, as opposed to only some, as is the case currently. The process will also be adapted to other ceramic, metallurgical and glass industries.

article.keywords: EcoStock, energy, heat, furnace, ceramic, electricity, industrial, waste, manufacture

project.teaser: Today heavy industries lose 20-40% of the energy they consume through waste heat. Above 200Â°C, these losses represent each year more than 4,000 TWhth, â‚¬200bn, 2,500 Mt CO2. Waste heat recovery solutions have emerged: they offer massive potential in costs/energy savings as...

article.title: Safeguarding our global airspace by improving drone integration
article.teaser: Drones present multiple opportunities, but also bring problems. The CLASS project has working on a surveillance tracking system to ensure drone usage is more effective and safer.

section.sectionBody:
As the number of potential drone applications grows, so too does their prevalence in the global airspace. This increase in usage brings with it significant potential pitfalls â€“ like the https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-sussex-46623754 (drone sightings that disrupted Gatwick airport in London, in December 2018).
Drones are difficult to detect and are often missed by conventional radars. increasing the risk of collision with other drones, or with other air traffic, even during non-confrontational drone flights. Regulation exists to manage this, but it is restrictive.
While authorities are working to reduce these restrictions, they have to do so in a way that guarantees a high level of airspace safety. The CLASS project worked to analyse tools and systems necessary to safely integrate drones into air traffic, creating a prototype traffic management system specifically designed to spot and incorporate evolving drone technology.

One of the major challenges that drones present is visibility. â€œAs pilots are not physically on the drones, they cannot see other drones. Even pilots on manned aircraft usually canâ€™t see drones, as they are too small.â€ explains Mr Alexandre Piot from Airbus and CLASS project coordinator. â€œCLASS investigated tools to build a comprehensive airspace picture, so that all air-users and authorities could see where drones are flying, to enforce safety in the sky.â€
The project has developed a prototype traffic management system, for https://www.airbus.com/defence/uav.html (Unmanned Aerial Systems) (UAS). The services this system offers will create open, fair and safe access to the shared airspace, helping drones share airspace safely with other air traffic.
CLASS focused on drone tracking, combining multiple data streams taken from tracking information and innovative radar systems. â€œOnce you can track the aircraft, you can organise the traffic, monitoring compliance with airspace rules and signalling alerts when potential collisions are detected,â€ says Mr Piot.
System functions include real-time drone tracking and display. Some of the more advanced functions include â€˜geo-fencingâ€™, which tells drone pilots if they are straying into unauthorised airspace; â€˜geo-cagingâ€™, if the drone leaves the area it is supposed to be in; and the detection and resolution of any emerging problems.

To test the system, the team flew drones at Deenethorpe airfield in the United Kingdom, collecting data from the tracker and radar. The team then cross-checked these data datasets to ensure that the system was identifying the same object. The real-time tracking system was tested, while other more complete demonstrations are currently ongoing around the world. At the moment, the radar system has a limited field of view, meaning it can only pick up small drones within five kilometres. While this is not sufficient to cover a whole country, they can protect sensitive areas like airports,â€ says Mr Piot.
The team faced some challenges during the project, not least from typical British weather. â€œThe weather in England mid-October can be really windy and rainy, which are challenges for drones!â€ explains Mr Piot.
Mr Piot says that the whole team strived to get the most out of the experience, even whilst interpreting complicated concepts such as https://www.sesarju.eu/U-space (U-space) â€“ a European concept of shared airspace â€“ to safely integrate drones into reality in Europe.
CLASS was funded within the framework of the SESAR Joint Undertaking, a public-private partnership set up to modernise Europeâ€™s air traffic management system.

article.keywords: CLASS, drones, airspace, tracking, safety, conflict, detection, resolution

article.title: New technology set to enable small-scale biofuel production
article.teaser: The technical concepts and approaches developed by a group of EU researchers could help local farmers transform small biomass feedstock into biofuel.

section.sectionBody:
Despite their promise of not competing with food production and having low carbon emissions, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Second-generation_biofuels (second-generation biofuels) like bioethanol remain grossly underused. One notable reason is that the large-scale production of such biofuels requires a massive concentration of organic matter, such as https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lignocellulosic_biomass (lignocellulosic biomass). Moreover, due to difficulty accessing the polymer sugars in the biomass matrix, the production process is expensive and complex. As a result, there is little opportunity for small rural players to get in the game.
But what if farmers could valorise the small biomass feedstock found locally and use it to produce biofuel? This is the challenge posed by the EU-funded BABET-REAL5 project.
â€œBABET-REAL5 aims to develop the technical concepts and approaches needed to enable the small-scale production of biofuels,â€ says GÃ©rard Vilarem, who serves as director of the https://www6.toulouse.inrae.fr/lca (Laboratory of Agro-Industrial Chemistry), president of the centre for technological resources, https://afcrt.com/les-crt/ (CRT), and BABET-REAL5 project coordinator.
â€œBecause this model is more favourable to regions that cannot provide high amounts of concentrated biomasses, it will support the development of rural economies.â€

Most second-generation biofuel production processes involve several complex and expensive stages generating pollutants that need to be cleaned up. What BABET-REAL5 aims to do is streamline this entire process into a single, compact system.
â€œOur main goal is to develop a compact system that can be easily installed in rural areas,â€ explains Vilarem. â€œWe also want a process that ensures maximum performance and zero waste while consuming little energy â€“ a real challenge when one considers the complex structure of lignocellulosic biomass.â€
Vilarem adds that the project also hopes to achieve techno-economic and environmental viability from processing just 30 000 tons of dry material annually, which is three to seven times less than the current business model. To do this, researchers created a prototype featuring a patented bioextrusion process that combines the various steps of the pretreatment phase into a single step.
â€œThe thermal, mechanical, chemical and biochemical reactions necessary to destruct the biomass and access the polymer sugar enzymes are now combined and performed at high throughput in one reactor,â€ explains Vilarem.
Next, researchers combined this pretreatment phase with the https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saccharification (saccharification) and fermentation phases, which is where the sugars are separated from the biomass and transformed into ethanol.
â€œWe have implemented these two steps inside one single reactor,â€ notes Vilarem. â€œWe also optimised them to demonstrate the feasibility of the entire continuous process, from pretreatment of the biomass to the production of ethanol at pilot scale.â€

According to Vilarem, the project succeeded in accomplishing its main objectives: â€œThe results demonstrate that most of the studied business cases are technically, economically and environmentally viable at small industrial scale.â€
Although the project has successfully advanced the new technical steps to pilot scale, they are still a long way from industrialisation.
However, based on the encouraging results achieved during this project, the consortium is now considering developing a demonstration unit. During this stage, researchers hope to scale up the BABET-REAL5 technologies to industrial-scale production levels.

article.keywords: BABET-REAL5, biofuel, biomass, carbon emissions, second-generation biofuels, bioethanol, farmers, rural economies, ethanol

project.teaser: The business model currently under development for second generation ethanol is a replication of the model used for first generation which is plants with massive annual production capacities. Such high production rates require high capital investment and huge amounts of...
